INTRODUCTION A Framework for Innovation:Finding Problems Worth Working On Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 1 1

Creative Destruction Capitalism…is by nature a form or method of economic change…. The fundamental impulse that sets and keeps the capitalist engine in motion comes from the new consumers’ goods, the new methods of production or transportation, the new markets, the new forms of industrial organization that capitalist enterprise creates…. The opening up of new markets, foreign or domestic… illustrate the process of industrial mutation that incessantly revolutionizes the economic structure from within, incessantly destroying the old one, incessantly creating a new one. This process of Creative Destruction is the essential fact about capitalism. It is what capitalism consists in and what every capitalist concern has got to live in. Confidential for classroom use only 2 Joseph Alois Schumpeter (1883 – 1950, Harvard). Joseph A. Schumpeter, Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy (Harper & Brothers: 1942). 2

Entrepreneurship and Innovation ‘The entrepreneur,’ said the French economist J. B. Say around 1800, ‘shifts economic resources out of an area of lower and into an area of higher productivity and greater yield.’ Entrepreneurs innovate. Innovation is the specific instrument of entrepreneurship. It is the act that endows resources with a new capacity to create wealth. Confidential for classroom use only 3 Peter Drucker, Innovation and Entrepreneurship (Routledge Classics, 1985). Taylor and Francis. Kindle Edition. Entrepreneurs innovate. Innovation is the specific instrument of entrepreneurship. It is the act that endows resources with a new capacity to create wealth. Innovation, indeed, creates a resource 3

Defining Innovation (per the OED) From the 16th century: The action of innovating; the introduction of novelties; the alteration of what is established by the introduction of new elements or forms. Revolution. A change made in the nature or fashion of anything; something newly introduced; a novel practice, method, etc.

From the 20th century The action of introducing a new product into the market; a product newly brought on to the market. 4 https://biblio.com.au/book/supplement-oxford-english-dictionary-vols-i/d/512062367 https://www.oed.com/dictionary/innovation_n?tab=meaning_and_use Confidential: For Classroom Use Only I like to begin with defining what we are talking about.  So what is “innovation?”  Very simply it is something new. 4

Innovation is Driven by Maturing Markets Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 5 At some point, market growth must slow. It may still be possible for a few firms to keep growing fast by attracting customers from competitors, but this is likely to be increasingly difficult. Another possibility is to expand into new geographic markets, but there are often real limits to this approach. Leading a process of industry consolidation by absorbing competitors can also bring continued growth for some time. But there are obvious limits to this source of growth as well. Thus, if a firm is to continue to grow at substantial rates, it must ultimately be by developing business opportunities beyond its original scope. Acquisitions are one way to get into new businesses. Acquisitions readily lead to higher sale numbers and higher total profits, but the implications for value creation and profitability are less clearly positive. In general, it seems very hard for firms to benefit their owners by buying other firms. The difficulties are twofold. First is to avoid having
avoid having all the potential value creation flow to the shareholders of the acquired firm. The second is to realize the potential gains once the transaction is completed.
John Roberts, The Modern Firm (Oxford University Press: 2004). But what drives innovation? 5

Innovation is Driven by Shifting Competitive Advantage Per Michael Porter, innovations shift competitive advantage by changing the status quo: New technologies; New or shifting buyer needs; The emergence of a new industry segment; Shifting input costs or availability; and Changes in government regulation. 6 https://www.fsg.org/people/michael-e-porter/Michael Porter, The Competitive Advantage of Nations (The Free Press: 1990). Confidential: For Classroom Use Only Innovations shift competitive advantage form one company to another, hopefully in your direction. It changes the status quo. 6

Innovation is Driven by Change ‘Innovation’, then, is an economic or social rather than a technical term. It can be defined the way J. B. Say defined entrepreneurship, as changing the yield of resources. Or, as a modern economist would tend to do, it can be defined in demand terms rather than in supply terms, that is, as changing the value and satisfaction obtained from resources by the consumer. Systematic innovation therefore consists in the purposeful and organized search for changes, and in the systematic analysis of the opportunities such changes might offer for economic or social innovation. The overwhelming majority of successful innovations exploit change. To be sure, there are innovations that in themselves constitute a major change; some of the major technical innovations, such as the Wright Brothers’ aeroplane, are examples. But these are exceptions, and fairly uncommon ones. Most successful innovations are far more prosaic; they exploit change. And thus the discipline of innovation (and it

and it is the knowledge base of entrepreneurship) is a diagnostic discipline: a systematic examination of the areas of change that typically offer entrepreneurial opportunities. Confidential for classroom use only 7 Peter Drucker, Innovation and Entrepreneurship (Routledge Classics, 1985). Taylor and Francis. Kindle Edition.

The Institutional Enablers of Innovation In a study of the Tokyo Rope Corporation (Tokyo Seiko) in the Meiji era (1868-1911), the researchers point out three factors essential for innovation: rebuilding a corporate governance structure for ambidexterity, which refers balancing the exploitation of existing products with the exploration of new developments; intellectual communication between academic researchers and practitioners; and smooth B2B transactions where effective external relationships efficiently align company R&D efforts, products offered, and customer needs.

8 https://intmech.vn/san-pham/tokyo-rope-shinko-cap-thep/ https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/119536/1/MPRA_paper_119536.pdf Confidential: For Classroom Use Only Another important point about the nature of innovation.  According to James March, successful companies must both exploit and explore. Exploration – you do not always know where you are going.  Important to explore in many directions, because you do not know ahead of time how things will turn out. 8

The End Goal: An Innovative Startup (with a HEART) H: Hypothesis / Start with Why Why are you starting this startup? What do you believe about your target market? Express this as an “I believe” statement - what you believe is broken, or is a need or opportunity that has not yet been met. E: Enormous Stakes Express the size and scope of the problem or opportunity, in terms of how many people or companies it impacts, how much money is at stake, etc. A: Alternatives Grossly Inadequate Briefly state the way(s) this problem/opportunity is addressed today, and how those approaches or solutions all fall terribly short. Give brief names or examples of current solutions if relevant. R: Radically different solution Briefly describe what your solution does, how it is radically different (ideally 10x better, paradigm shift, game-changing), and how it comprehensively solves the problem

the problem/opportunity. T: Traits and skills (of the team) Describe the roles (who is responsible for what) on the Team, and the factual background that gives them credibility for these roles Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 9 From Ben Weiner
FINDING PROBLEMS WORTH SOLVING Confidential for classroom use only 10

Entrepreneurship and Entrepreneurs According to Robert Baron, entrepreneurs use cognitive frameworks to “connect the dots” between changes in technology, demographics, markets, government policies, and other factors, and then use the  patterns they then perceive in these events or trends suggest ideas for new products or services—ideas that can potentially serve as the basis for new ventures. According to Mark Casson, the essence of entrepreneurship is being different, having a different perception of the situation, and placing a bet based on his superior judgment According to Jeffrey Timmons the entrepreneurial process includes Opportunity Resources The team And entrepreneurs are people who Create and recognize opportunities Take the initiative to seize opportunities Take personal and financial risks Devise strategies to utilize limited resources Build a team with complementary skills and talents
Getting Started What is your big idea for a startup…? Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 12

Principles: Finding the Best Opportunities Purposeful, systematic innovation begins with the analysis of the opportunities. Innovation is both conceptual and perceptual. The second imperative of innovation is therefore to go out to look, to ask, to listen. An innovation, to be effective, has to be simple and it has to be focused. Effective innovations start small. They are not grandiose. They try to do one specific thing.

Finally, there are three conditions: Innovation is work. It requires knowledge. It often requires great ingenuity. To succeed, innovators must build on their strengths. Successful innovators look at opportunities over a wide range. But then they ask, ‘Which of these opportunities fits me, fits this company, puts to work what we (or I) are good at and have shown capacity for in performance?’ And finally, innovation is an effect in economy and society, a change in the behaviour of customers, of teachers, of farmers, of eye surgeons – of people in general. Or it is a change in a process – that is, in how people work and produce something. Innovation therefore always has to be close to the market, focused on the market, indeed market-driven. Confidential for classroom use only 13 Peter Drucker, Innovation and Entrepreneurship (Routledge Classics, 1985). Taylor and Francis. Kindle Edition. Entrepreneurship is about purposeful, systematic

, systematic innovation and begins with the hunt for opportunities. Opportunities are invariably thought about as problems and needs. Our task – finding the best opportunities means finding the best problems. 13

The Sources of Opportunities History tells us that there are four common sources of opportunities – opportunities that are more than mere ideas – that any would-be entrepreneur can use. Opportunities created by macro trends in society Opportunities found by living and experiencing the customer problem Opportunities created through scientific research Opportunities proven elsewhere that you can pursue here. 14 https://tedxlondonbusinessschool.co.uk/john-mullins/ John Mullins, “Entrepreneurial Gold Mines” in Business Strategy Review (Spring 2004). Confidential: For Classroom Use Only So where do new things come from? 14
Components of Innovation The components of innovation include: A problem worth solving A solution that solves the problem A business case that allows the solution to enter the market and to scale

All must be validated Is the problem worth working on? Does the solution address the problem effectively and efficiently? Does the business case allow the solution to move forward and does it work for all stakeholders? Confidential for classroom use only 15 15
Finding Good Problems Innovation and entrepreneurship begin with finding problems worth solving Because not all problems are of equal value or importance

What are good problems? Per Frans Johansson, the best innovative ideas are those which are new and valuable and surprising Those that create a new future Key question:  How do you find them? Confidential for classroom use only 16 Frans Johansson, The Medici Effect (Harvard Business School Press: 2006) 16

Traditional Answer: Get Out of the Building From grocer to philanthropist, a man named Johns Hopkins laid out a plan to use his wealth to establish a hospital that would provide care to anyone, regardless of sex, age or race. This hospital would be named The Johns Hopkins Hospital and opened in 1889, with The Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine four years later. These events marked a new era for medical education and patient care. Confidential for classroom use only 17 https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/about/history/history-of-jhh/index.html https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_Hospital#/media/File:Johns_Hopkins_Hospital_in_Baltimore_1900s.jpg 17

Example: Getting Out of the Building Confidential for classroom use only 18 A new product from six Johns Hopkins University grad students updates current IV infiltration detection tech to help cancer patients avoid a condition called lymphedema. The term refers to a gradual buildup of lymphatic fluid in the extremities, often following cancer treatment, that causes swelling and pain. It’s treatable if caught early, but once a patient feels something wrong, it’s typically too late. To fight this, the students developed LymphaSense, which acts as a noninvasive patch-like sensor for patients to test fluid levels.

The Challenge of Presentism Great innovation usually starts with a problem to solve. But great problems rarely present themselves on their own and are not always obvious. The key to groundbreaking innovation is identifying what the next great problem actually is. Problems are discovered not only by getting out of the building, but by getting out of your head — and your current frame of reference. Framing an Ill-Defined Problem How can we clean up pollution in waterways? This is not a problem that can be solved because it is unclear what exactly you are cleaning up, and how.

It should be noted that the terms well-defined and ill-defined are not evaluative when applied to problem situations; that is, a well-defined problem is not in any way a better problem than an ill-defined one, nor is it necessarily easier to solve. Rather, well- and ill-defined are descriptive terms, which simply tell you how much information you are given before you begin to solve the problem. Ill-defined problems require that the problem solver specify some missing elements before working out a solution can occur. Confidential for classroom use only 6 Robert W. Weisberg, Creativity (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.: 2006). 6

The Process for Creating an Ill-Defined Problem Start with the domain of interest – e.g., How can we clean up pollution in waterways? Ocean Inland Create an ill-defined problem: e.g., How can we clean up trash from inland waterways? Create a list of opportunities

EXTENSIVE SEARCHING:THE MEDICI EFFECT FRANS JOHANSSON(HARVARD BUSINESS PRESS: 2006) Confidential for classroom use only 12 Example of intersectional ideas 12

Two Kinds of Innovation The major difference between a directional idea and an intersectional one is that we know where we are going with the former. Directional innovation improves a product in fairly predictable steps, along a well-defined dimension…. The goal is to evolve an established idea by using refinements and adjustments. The rewards for doing so are reasonably predictable and attained relatively quickly. Intersectional innovations, on the other hand, change the world in leaps along new directions. They usually pave the way for a new field and therefore make it possible for the people who originated them to become the leaders in the fields they created. Intersectional innovations also do not require as much expertise as directional innovation and can therefore be executed by the people you least suspect.
Confidential for classroom use only 13

Intersectional Ideas …what we are really saying is that the people in the program have managed to connect these fields, and through these connections the have come up with new creative insights. The term field is used in this book to describe disciplines, cultures, and domains in which one can specialize through education, work, hobbies, traditions, or other life experiences…. Fields consist of concepts such as knowledge and practices…. In order to understand a field, one has to understand at least some of its concepts. The key difference between a field and an intersection of fields lies in how concepts within them are combined. If you operate within a field, you primarily are able to combine concepts within that particular field, generating ideas that evolve along a particular direction – what I call directional ideas. When you step into the Intersection, you combine concepts between multiple fields, generating ideas that leap in new directions – what I call intersectional ideas. Confidential for classroom use only 14

Characteristics Intersectional innovations share the following characteristics: They are surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating. The take leaps in new directions. They open up entirely new fields. They provide a space for a person, team, or company to call its own. They generate followers, which means the creators can become leaders. They provide a source of directional innovation for years or decades to come. They can affect the world in unprecedented ways.

There are three distinct forces behind the rise of intersections, and at this moment, perhaps for the first time, they are all working together. The movement of people The convergence of science The leap of computation Confidential for classroom use only 15 Intersectional ideas are where we put two things together in surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating ways. The key is that the combination is unexpected 15

Example: Celcy Two Baltimore natives and Johns Hopkins graduates have created a smart appliance system to make it easier for families and working professionals to have a home-prepared meal without having to cook it themselves. Celcy stores frozen meals on one side of the appliance, moves them to its oven side when they’re ready to be prepared, cooks the meals, and tracks users’ preferences to offer suggestions. Users can schedule meals at a particular time and, using a mobile app, direct Celcy to unpack and cook meals. Confidential for classroom use only 16 https://celcy.com

Associations and Associative Barriers …the mind unravels a chain of associations. By simply hearing a word or seeing an image, the mind unlocks a whole string of associated ideas, each one connecting to another. These chains tend to be clustered around domains related to our own experience… Chains of association are efficient; they allow us to move quickly from analysis to action. Although chains of association have huge benefits, they also carry costs. They inhibit our ability to think broadly. In the search for intersections, low barriers provide an advantage. The problem is that there are strong benefits to keeping our natural cognitive barriers in place. Our brain evolved the way it did for a reason. It generally enjoys finding order in things, grouping concepts together, and finding structure in the environment surrounding it. A person with high associative barriers will quickly arrive at conclusions when confronted with a problem sine their thinking is more focused. He or she will recall how the problem has been handled in the past, or how others

how others in similar situations solved it. A person with low associative barriers, on the other hand, may think to connect ideas or concepts that have very little basis in past experience, or that can be traced logically. Confidential for classroom use only 17

How to Make Barriers Fall People succeed at breaking down their associative barriers because they did one or more of the following things: Exposed themselves to a range of cultures Learned differently Reversed their assumptions Took on multiple perspectives People step into the Intersection by generating lots of random combinations. How? By diversifying occupations, expanding networks and interacting with diverse groups of people, and going Intersection Hunting by searching for connections in unlikely places and then seeing where those connections lead.
Confidential for classroom use only 18 18

The Process Start with something of importance to you Put it together with a wide range of unrelated ideas or products or services What surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating (intersectional) ideas result from the combination? Where are the opportunities?

Alternatively: Who could you talk to (from an unrelated field) that could give you a different perspective on your field? Confidential for classroom use only 19 The more ideas the better; the goal is to increasing opportunities for serendipity, but also increasing opportunities where fortune can favor the prepared mind Extensive approach in order to explore more fields Intensive approach to explore a single field more deeply They both have merit 19

INTENSIVE SEARCHING: THE FOUR LENSES OF INNOVATION Rowan Gibson (John Wiley & Sons: 2015) Confidential for classroom use only 20 A way to find intersectional ideas Those thar are surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating 20

Two Constants If we strip the whole creative process down to its absolute basics, however, we find that there are in fact only two constants: two elements that can never be skipped and that always occur in exactly the same order. In fact, these two critical elements are indispensable to every single innovation story in the world: One element is the big idea. Obviously, at the heart of every significant innovation there is a compelling and value-creating idea of some kind—a new combination of thoughts. The other element is the illuminating insight (or insights). Without fail, every big idea was preceded by at least one insight—a new and penetrating understanding into a situation or problem. These two elements of the creative thinking process—the insight and the idea—are invariably present in each case, and are always inextricably connected. Why? Because if there was one universal law of innovation, it would be this: Powerful new ideas are never simply snatched out of the air. They are always inspired
always inspired by insights. Confidential for classroom use only 21

Four Lenses: The Sources of Insights As we have learned so far, there were four particular perspectives or patterns of thinking that became prevalent in the Renaissance period: Harnessing Trends:  Recognizing the future potential of emerging developments, and using these trends to open up new opportunities Understanding Needs:  Paying attention to issues and frustrations others have ignored, and experimenting with new solutions to problems Challenging Orthodoxies:  Questioning deeply entrenched beliefs and assumptions (i.e. received wisdom), and exploring new and highly unconventional answers Leveraging Resources:  Understanding our limitless capacity for redeploying skills and assets in new ways, combinations, or contexts Confidential for classroom use only 22 We will basically follow Gibson in the remaining slides 22

HARNESSING TRENDS What opportunities can be found by EXPLOITING MACRO-CHANGES? Confidential for classroom use only 23 Macro-trends are about the big changes that are actually happening out there; changes that will destroy companies, but also create opportunities Related to trend analysis 23

Example: Amazon Confidential for classroom use only 24 https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/amazon-now-employs-almost-1-million-people-u-s-or-n1275539 The company was created as a result of what Jeff Bezos called his regret minimization framework, which described his efforts to fend off any regrets for participating sooner in the Internet business boom during that time. In 1994, Bezos left his employment as vice-president of D.E. Shaw & Co., a Wall Street firm, and moved to Seattle, Washington, where he began to work on a business plan for what would become Amazon.com After reading a report about the future of the Internet that projected annual web commerce growth at 2,300%, Bezos created a list of 20 products that could be marketed online. He narrowed the list to what he felt were the five most promising products, which included: compact discs, computer hardware,

hardware, computer software, videos, and books. Bezos finally decided that his new business would sell books online, because of the large worldwide demand for literature, the low unit price for books, and the huge number of titles available in print. Amazon was founded in the garage of Bezos rented home in Bellevue, Washington. Bezos parents invested almost $250,000 in the start-up.
Example: Blockbuster Confidential for classroom use only 25 https://www.mentalfloss.com/article/75171/15-fast-forward-facts-about-blockbuster-video

Four Types of Macro Changes In general, four types of changes make opportunities for new businesses: changes in technology, changes in political and regulatory rules, changes in social and demographic factors, and changes in industry structure: …technological change allows people to do things that could not be done before or only could be done in a less efficient manner…. The magnitude of the technological change is important. The larger the technological change, the greater the opportunity for new businesses to be created because larger magnitude changes affect more uses for technology, allowing the use of new technology in more things. Why do political and regulatory changes enhance entrepreneurial opportunity? Deregulation creates opportunity because it allows more variance in ideas to be put forward by entrepreneurs who might have been barred from entry under a regulated regime. Social and demographic changes open up opportunities for new technology businesses by altering peoples preferences and creating demand for things where demand had not existed before. Sometimes, industry structure shifts because firms that supply other firms or major customers die or because firms merge

firms merge or acquire each other. These types of shifts change the competitive dynamics in an industry and open up or close down niches that may provide opportunities for entrepreneurs. Confidential for classroom use only 26 Scott A. Shane, Finding Fertile Ground (FT Press: 2004) Example of amazon 26

Examples From Charles Kirschbaum (Insper): Growing demand for eco-friendly products The health and wellness industry is experiencing significant growth, driven by factors such as an aging population The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the adoption of remote work and many employees do not want to return to face-to-face work Consumers increasingly seek personalized experiences and products Growing demand for businesses that prioritize social and environmental impact Confidential for classroom use only 27

Four Great Disruptive Forces Speed, surprise, and sudden shifts in direction in huge global markets routinely impact the destinies of established companies and provide opportunities for new entrants. In fact, ours is a world of near-constant discontinuity. Competitors can rise in almost complete stealth and burst upon the scene. Businesses that were protected by large and deep moats find that their defenses are easily breached. Vast new markets are conjured seemingly from nothing. Technology and globalization have accelerated and intensified the natural forces of market competition A radically different world is forming. The operating system of the world’s economy is being rewritten as we speak. It doesn’t come out in a splashy new release. It evolves, unfolds, and often explodes. The Four great disruptive forces: The shifting locus of economic activity The impact of technology Demographics Flows and Connectivity Confidential for classroom use only 28 Richard Dobbs, et.al., No Ordinary Disruption (Public
(Public Affairs: 2015)

The Metaverse …the metaverse is a combinatorial technology: it combines elements of many of the top trends that the McKinsey Technology Council identified this year as most promising, including AI, immersive reality, advanced connectivity, and Web3.

For now, to get a sense of the potential, consider two of the largest and more advanced uses, one for consumer businesses and one for B2B companies: Brand marketing and consumer engagement. Many companies have already added the metaverse to their omnichannel marketing mix, staking out a presence in virtual worlds like Roblox, Fortnite, and the Sandbox. Digital twins. In the metaverse, every asset, process, or person within and related to an enterprise can be replicated virtually—and connected. As a result, nearly every aspect of work can take place digitally before it does so physically. By building digital twins—virtual replicas of physical settings and objects in a metaverse that generate data in real time—far richer analyses can be generated to enable improved decision making.

WICKED PROBLEMS Confidential for classroom use only 4

Defining Wicked Problems A wicked problem is a social or cultural problem that is difficult or impossible to solve for as many as four reasons: incomplete or contradictory knowledge, the number of people and opinions involved, the large economic burden, and the interconnected nature of these problems with other problems. Example: poverty is linked with education, nutrition with poverty, the economy with nutrition, and so on.

These problems are typically offloaded to policy makers, or are written off as being too cumbersome to handle en masse. Yet these are the problems—poverty, sustainability, equality, and health and wellness—that plague our cities and our world and that touch each and every one of us.

Confidential for classroom use only 5 https://ssir.org/books/excerpts/entry/wicked_problems_problems_worth_solving# It is the interconnectedness of the problems that gives scope for systems thinking 5

Characteristics of Wicked Problems Horst Rittel, one of the first to formalize a theory of wicked problems, cites ten characteristics of these complicated social issues: Wicked problems have no definitive formulation. The problem of poverty in Texas is grossly similar but discretely different from poverty in Nairobi, so no practical characteristics describe “poverty.” It’s hard, maybe impossible, to measure or claim success with wicked problems because they bleed into one another, unlike the boundaries of traditional design problems that can be articulated or defined. Solutions to wicked problems can be only good or bad, not true or false. There is no idealized end state to arrive at, and so approaches to wicked problems should be tractable ways to improve a situation rather than solve it. There is no template to follow when tackling a wicked problem, although history may provide a guide. Teams that approach wicked problems must literally make things up as they go along. There is always more than one explanation

one explanation for a wicked problem, with the appropriateness of the explanation depending greatly on the individual perspective of the designer. Every wicked problem is a symptom of another problem. The interconnected quality of socio-economic political systems illustrates how, for example, a change in education will cause new behavior in nutrition. No mitigation strategy for a wicked problem has a definitive scientific test because humans invented wicked problems and science exists to understand natural phenomena. Offering a “solution” to a wicked problem frequently is a “one shot” design effort because a significant intervention changes the design space enough to minimize the ability for trial and error. Every wicked problem is unique. Designers attempting to address a wicked problem must be fully responsible for their actions.
Confidential for classroom use only 6 https://ssir.org/books/excerpts/entry/wicked_problems_problems_worth_solving# 6

Reminder: What are Systems? ﻿A system is an interconnected set of elements that is coherently organized in a way that achieves something. If you look at that definition closely for a minute, you can see that a system must consist of three kinds of things: elements, interconnections, and a function or purpose. ﻿Systems can be embedded in systems, which are embedded in yet other systems. Is there anything that is not a system? Yes—a conglomeration without any particular interconnections or function. Sand scattered on a road by happenstance is not, itself, a system. ﻿A system is more than the sum of its parts. It may exhibit adaptive, dynamic, goal-seeking, self-preserving, and sometimes evolutionary behavior. Confidential for classroom use only 8 Thinking in Systems by Donella H. Meadows, ﻿Edited by Diana Wright (Sustainability Institute: Chelsea Green Publishing, 2008)

Implications A system is the product of the interactions of its subsystems, and not the sum of its parts. To improve the system, do not focus on improving the performance of its parts, but how well the parts interact. Sometimes it is necessary to worsen the performance of a part of the system in order to improve the functioning of the whole (e.g., an engine that is too powerful for a car’s transmission or brakes). Other times the interrelationship needs to be changed or improved. There is, therefore, no such thing as a ‘marketing’… ‘sales’… ‘production’… ‘personnel’… ‘financial’… problem. The solution is, in the majority of cases, in areas different from where they appear (e.g., a sales problem may be due to a production coordination problem), and lies instead in the interactions of these subsystems. You Try It – Where are the S’s and O’s? An “s” (or “+”) indicates that as one variable changes, the next variable changes in the same direction. (Or, the first variable adds to the second variable.) An “o” (or “-”) indicates that as one variable changes, the other variable changes in the opposite direction. (Or, the first variable subtracts from the second variable.) Caution: once a loop gets going, it is hard to tell what is driving what.

ChemBE Example: Reinforcing Loop This figure shows a reinforcing feedback effect. Natural gas power plants need various infrastructure investments which consist of pipelines, fuel processing facilities, and storage. When the pipeline infrastructure exists, several gas plants can benefit from it. If pipelines are not present, natural gas has to be processed into transportable forms such as LNG. Installing pipelines reduces the transportation costs for future natural gas plant investments. In turn, gas plants become more attractive to invest in. Moreover, installing natural gas plants would make it more attractive to invest in natural gas infrastructure for reducing costs. In this type of feedback, the elements are reinforcing each other because an initial increase in one of the variables leads to a further increase of that same variable through the other variables. The opposite also holds: an initial decrease of one of the variables leads to a further decrease of that same variable through the other variables. Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 16 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/
science/article/pii/S1364032120308364

ChemBE Example: Balancing Loop This figure shows a balancing feedback effect. In this type of feedback, the elements in the feedback loop affect each other until a goal is reached. An initial increase of a variable leads to a decrease of that same variable, through the other variables. This effect continues until the system is in equilibrium. To illustrate, the relationship between the energy gap and power plants can be considered. An energy gap occurs when the energy demand cannot be met with current capacities. To provide uninterrupted energy, new investments are required. Installing power plants will satisfy the energy gap. In this type of feedback, the elements cease to change their levels when the goal is reached. These feedbacks are called balancing feedbacks since they have a stabilizing effect on the system. Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 17 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364032120308364

Stock and Flow Diagrams Confidential for classroom use only 19

Advantages of Stock and Flow Diagrams System Dynamics has two main types of diagramming approaches: Causal Loop Diagrams (CLD) and Stock and Flow Diagrams (SFD). CLD representations of various feedback loops. CLDs are appropriate when the aim is understanding and visualizing the feedback structure of a system. CLDs can help us model complex systems in an accessible way. However, CLDs become ambiguous when aggregating certain variables and structures for the sake of simplicity. SFDs can overcome CLDs’ ambiguity because they differentiate between stocks and flows. Stocks are state variables. They represent the variables in the system which accumulate or deplete over time and thus have a certain level (or state) at a given time. Flows are the rates that alter the stocks. Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 20 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364032120308364

ChemBE Example Natural gas plant capacity is a stock. Investments in natural gas is an example of an inflow and depreciation of natural gas is an example of an outflow. When an investment decision is made, it typically takes two to three years to build a natural gas plant and a gas plants economic lifetime is approximately 30 years. Therefore, changes in stocks are not instantaneous but rather they happen over time through connected flows as shown here. Distinguishing stocks and flows provides a better operational representation of the system. SFDs also provide a starting point for quantification in future research. For these reasons, we have chosen to use SFDs. Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 21 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364032120308364

Comparing Causal Loop Diagrams and Stocks and Flows For example, consider the simple reinforcing loop of Births and Population. Because Births is a flow (representing the rate of increase in Population), and Population is a stock, a CLD (causal loop diagram) does not represent this system as accurately as does a stock and flow diagram. In the CLD, both links in this loop are “s” links, indicating that as Births increase, Population increases (a change in the same direction), and as Population increases, Births increase (another change in the same direction). However, this representation is not completely accurate. If Birth Rate declines, causing Births to decrease, say from 1000 to 900 per month, Population does not in turn decrease; it continues to increase, only at a slower rate than before. Thus the “s” link from Births to Population is accurate only when Births is increasing, because Births and Population

and Population do not move in the same direction when Births decrease. In contrast, a stock and flow diagram makes it visually apparent that Births is an inflow to Population and thus can only increase it, not decrease it (because there cannot be a negative number of births). This distinction between stocks and flows makes stock and flow diagrams a more accurate rendition of the system being represented. Summary R1 (Fish Regenera8on Loop): More adult fish leads to more regeneration rate for a given fractional regeneration rate, which generates more adult fish a9er the maturation time delay. This is the key regeneration loop that causes fish population to grow over time . B2 (Limits to Growth Loop): Healthy ecosystem in the diagram denotes carrying capacity. There is a carrying capacity in the marine ecosystem that supports a given amount of fish population. More fish, higher fish density for a given carrying capacity (thus less nutrients per fish), which leads to lower fractional regeneration rate. When total fish population reaches its carrying capacity, reproduction slows down, as there is no more capacity to support further population growth. Starting from a small population relative to this carrying capacity, the fish population over time will grow and eventually stabilizes near this carrying capacity. R2 (Race for Fish Loop): less adult fish stock, less catch per unit effort, which lowers fishing income and drives up fishing effort.

The Problem of Electrification How did the small, intercity lighting systems of the 1880s evolve into the regional power systems of the 1920s? Electric power systems embody the physical, intellectual, and symbolic resources of the society that constructs them. The goal of an electric production system, for example, is to transform available energy supply, or input, into desired output, or demand. Because the components are related by the network of interconnections, the state, or activity, of one component influences the state, or activity, of other components in the system. The network provides a distinctive configuration for the system. For example, a system can have its components arranged vertically or horizontally.
Confidential for classroom use only 4 i.e., system growth 4
How do you Electrify Everything? Confidential for classroom use only 5 The System in 1900 One answer – build lots of little generating stations 5
The System in 1930 Confidential for classroom use only 6 The single-phase alternating-current system originated as a solution to a critical (transmission) problem in the direct-current system.
Engineers and managers had greatly improved the d.c. system, but they remained stymied by the cost of transmission beyond a radius of several miles.
Like the computing industry between 1980 and 1995 – when did it all change? 6

The Idea of a Reverse Salient A reverse salient appears in an expanding system when a component of the system does not march along harmoniously with other components. As the system evolves toward a goal, some components fall behind or out of line. As a result of the reverse salient, growth of the entire enterprise is hampered, or thwarted, and thus remedial action is required. The idea of a reverse salient suggests the need for concentrated action (invention and development) if expansion is to proceed. Having identified the reverse salients, the system tenders can then analyze them as a series of critical problems. Defining reverse salient problems is the essence of the creative process.
Confidential for classroom use only 7

Reverse Salient: The High Cost of Transmission Confidential for classroom use only 8 Reverse salients will change over time – from a focus on scientific to technical to economic and managerial problems. The salient can be addressed technologically/economically and/or politically/socially 8

Correcting Reverse Salients Innumerable (probably most) inventions and technological developments result from efforts to correct reverse salients. Outstanding inventions and developments in electric lighting and power during the two decades after 1880 were responses to reverse salients. Independent inventors—and later, inventors and industrial scientists hired by business enterprises—applied themselves to solving the problems inherent in reverse salients. They approached the challenge as inventors and engineers usually do—by defining the reverse salient as a set of “critical problems,” problems whose solution  would bring the system back into line—i.e., correct the reverse salient. Confidential for classroom use only 9 The correction can be technological, economic, social, or political 9

One Answer: Change the System When engineers correct reverse salients by solving critical problems, the system usually grows if there is adequate demand for its product. On occasion, however, a critical problem cannot be solved. For instance, the first of the major types of electric systems, direct current, had a reverse salient in that it was uneconomical to transmit. Despite precise definitions of the problem, the direct-current inventors and engineers could not in the 1880s find a solution. As a result, other inventors found a solution outside the d.c. system, and for a time the two systems were in conflict. After a compromise was worked out, the two systems existed in a complementary way until the newer system became the dominant one. Thus, this study offers an explanation not only of the evolution of systems as reverse salients are identified and solved, but also of the occasional emergence of new systems out of the failure to solve critical problems in the context of the old. AC Also had Reverse Salients Comparable to the transmission problem that had frustrated the direct-current inventors, the most serious problem for the alternating-current system was the need for a practical motor. Another problem stemmed from the use of higher voltages in a.c. practice than in d.c. and the resulting need to insulate and ground circuits to guard against injury and death from electric shocks. While “the battle of the currents” was being fought in the nontechnical arena, the new generation of engineers and inventors worked to solve the motor and safety problems. Confidential for classroom use only 12 The solution would be an alternating-current, polyphase motor. 12

The Solution The concept of a universal system completed the transition from the era of electric light to the era of electric light and power. The essence of the concept was a unified system embracing, or coupling, generators (supply) and loads of varying characteristics (demand). The system was  capable of supplying incandescent lamps, arc lights, direct current motors for both stationary and traction purposes, single-phase alternating-current motors, polyphase motors, and energy for thermo-electrical and electrochemical uses from a common transmission line or ring fed by centralized, large-scale generators. It is important to observe, however, that the struggle between the two systems did not come to an end with the development of a technical solution— couplers joining the old and new; it came with the introduction of institutional inventions that in turn resolved the conflict on the organizational level. Opportunities are ideas, insights, problems worth solving, but they cannot be solved until they are well-defined
Opportunities are conceptual
Reminder: Finding Opportunities is the Key
Definition: an occasion or situation that makes it possible to do something that you want to do or have to do, or the possibility of doing something
Opportunities are possibilities.
Opportunities are found when things don’t work as they should, or need to work better than they currently do.
Opportunities, therefore, can be thought of as problems to be solved, where the solutions allow us to create a different future.
Opportunities must be researched and explored if they are to be turned into well-defined problems and thus become innovations.

Example: How to Get to the Moon and Back? On 20 July 1969, the Eagle module from Apollo 11 landed at Tranquility Base. Hours later, at 21:56 CT (02:56 GMT), Neil Armstrong made history by becoming the first person to walk on the Moon. Originally inspired by the USs Cold War rivalry with the Soviet Union, the mission is now remembered as an iconic moment for stargazers all over the world. Armstrong was joined on the mission by his crewmates Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins. All three were born in 1930. Aldrin and Collins are still alive, but Armstrong died in 2012 at the age of 82. Michael Collins, the third crew member, told Fox News that its not very often he thinks about the mission. I lead a quiet life, he said. Ill be walking along down my street at night, when its starting to get dark, and I sense something over my right shoulder - and I look up and see that little silver

little silver sliver up there and think, Oh, thats the Moon! Ive been there! Confidential for classroom use only 8 Buzz Aldrin became the second person to walk on the Moon https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49060410

Example: How to Prevent Skidding: Anti-Lock Brakes Stopping a car in a hurry on a slippery road can be very challenging. Anti-lock braking systems (ABS) take a lot of the challenge out of this sometimes-nerve-wracking event. In fact, on slippery surfaces, even professional drivers cant stop as quickly without ABS as an average driver can with ABS. The theory behind anti-lock brakes is simple. A skidding wheel (where the tire contact patch is sliding relative to the road) has less traction than a non-skidding wheel. If you have been stuck on ice, you know that if your wheels are spinning you have no traction. This is because the contact patch is sliding relative to the ice. By keeping the wheels from skidding while you slow down, anti-lock brakes benefit you in two ways: Youll stop faster, and youll be able to steer while you stop. Confidential for classroom use
classroom use only 9 https://auto.howstuffworks.com/auto-parts/brakes/brake-types/anti-lock-brake.htm Solving a well-defined problem can also open up new possibilities. 9

Develop a Good Problem Statement Getting a crystal‐clear definition of the problem you are solving is the critical starting point to bulletproof problem solving. You need to be clear about the boundaries of the problem, the criteria for success, the time frame, or level of accuracy required.

Good problem statements have a number of characteristics. They are: Outcomes focused: A clear statement of the problem to be solved, expressed in outcomes, not activities or intermediate outputs. Specific and measurable wherever possible. Clearly time‐bound. Designed to explicitly address decision‐maker values and boundaries, including the accuracy needed and the scale of aspirations. Structured to allow sufficient scope for creativity and unexpected results—too narrowly scoped problems can artificially constrain solutions. Solved at the highest level possible, meaning for the organization as a whole, not just optimized for a part or a partial solution.

Mind Mapping A mind map is a diagram used to represent words, ideas, tasks, or other items linked to and arranged radially around a central key word or idea. Mind maps are used to generate, visualize, structure, and classify ideas, and as an aid in study, organization, problem solving, decision making, and writing. The elements of a given mind map are arranged intuitively according to the importance of the concepts, and are classified into groupings, branches, or areas, with the goal of representing semantic or other connections between portions of information. Mind maps may also aid recall of existing memories. By presenting ideas in a radial, graphical, non-linear manner, mind maps encourage a brainstorming approach to planning and organizational tasks. Though the branches of a mind map represent hierarchical tree structures, their radial arrangement disrupts the prioritizing of concepts typically associated with hierarchies presented with more linear visual cues. This orientation towards brainstorming encourages users to enumerate and connect concepts without a tendency
a tendency to begin within a particular conceptual framework. Confidential for classroom use only 14

The Rules of Mind Mapping The rules of mind mapping are “intended to help you to a free and good judgment.” They are “the children of sound experience,” having been extensively tested and refined over the past thirty years. All you need to begin mind mapping is a topic, a few colored pens, and a large sheet of paper. Follow these rules: Begin your mind map with a symbol or a picture (representing your topic) at the center of your page. Starting at the center opens your mind to a full 360 degrees of association. Pictures and symbols are much easier to remember than words and enhance your ability to think creatively about your subject. Write down key words. Key words are the information-rich “nuggets” of recall and creative association. Connect the key words with lines radiating from your central image. By linking words with lines (“branches”), you’ll show clearly how one key word relates to

relates to another. Print your key words. Printing is easier to read and remember than writing. Print one key word per line. By doing this, you free yourself to discover the maximum number of creative associations for each key word. The discipline of one word per line also trains you to focus on the most appropriate key word, enhancing the precision of your thought and minimizing clutter. Print your key words on the lines and make the length of the word the same as the line it is on. This maximizes clarity of association and encourages economy of space. Use colors, pictures, dimension, and codes for greater association and emphasis. Highlight important points and illustrate relationships between different branches of your mind map. You might, for instance, prioritize your main points through color coding, highlighting in yellow the most important points, using blue for secondary points, and so forth. Pictures and images, preferably in vivid color, should be used wherever possible; they stimulate your creative association and greatly enhance your memory.
Confidential for classroom use only 15

Step 1 Let’s say that the topic for this mind map is the Renaissance. Start your mind map by drawing a representative image in the middle of the paper. Draw it as vividly as you can, using more than one color. Have fun and don’t worry about the accuracy of your drawing.
Confidential for classroom use only 16
Step 2 Now print key words or draw images on lines radiating out from your central image. Remember print on the lines, one key word or image per line, and keep the lines connected.
Confidential for classroom use only 17

Step 3 When you feel you have generated enough material through free association, look at the result: all your ideas spread across one page. As you examine your mind map, you will see relationships that help you organize and integrate your ideas. Look for words that appear repeatedly throughout map. They often suggest major themes.
Confidential for classroom use only 18

Step 4 Connect related parts of your mind map with arrows, codes, and colors. Eliminate elements that seem extraneous. Pare your mind map down to just the ideas you need for your purpose. Then put them in sequence, if necessary. This can be accomplished with numbers or by redrawing the mind map in clockwise order.
Confidential for classroom use only 19

How Do You Know When You Are Finished? Theoretically, a mind map never ends. As Da Vinci emphasized, “Everything is connected to everything else.” If you had the time, energy, inclination, enough colored pens, and a big enough piece of paper, you could go on linking all your knowledge and ultimately all human knowledge. Of course, if you are planning a speech or studying for an examination, you probably don’t have time to link all human knowledge. The simple answer is that your mind map is finished when the information you have generated meets your objectives for the task at hand.
Confidential for classroom use only 20

Summary A mind map is a diagram used to visually organize information in a hierarchical and spatial structure. A key concept or problem is drawn in the center and a collection of relevant topics is arranged in a radial structure about this concept or problem. Step 1: Define the main concept or problem. Identify the main concept or problem one would like to explore using a short phrase or sentence. One can also add a drawing or picture to represent the concept or the problem at hand. Step 2: Define the primary branches. Create as many primary branches needed which directly relate to the main concept or problem, placing them in a radial hierarchy structure. Choosing the “right” primary branches is important, as this will facilitate the thinking at lower levels of the hierarchy. If these primary branches are too general or too specific, they may constrain ones’ thinking and creativity. Step 3: Define the sub‐branches. Create as many sub‐branches as needed. Sub‐br
‐branches stem from the primary branches in order to further expand a given concept. This process may continue until one reaches the desired level of granularity.
Confidential for classroom use only 21 Avner Engel. Practical Creativity and Innovation in Systems Engineering (Wiley Series in Systems Engineering and Management). Kindle Edition: 2018. 21

Finding the Root Cause: The Five Why’s The vehicle did not start. (the problem) Why? - The battery is dead. (First why) Why? - The alternator is not functioning. (Second why) Why? - The alternator belt has broken. (Third why) Why? - The alternator belt was well beyond its useful service life and not replaced. (Fourth why) Why? - The vehicle was not maintained according to the recommended service schedule. (Fifth why, a root cause) The questioning for this example could be taken further to a sixth, seventh, or higher level, but five iterations of asking why is generally sufficient to get to a root cause. The key is to encourage the trouble-shooter to avoid assumptions and logic traps and instead trace the chain of causality in direct increments from the effect through any layers of abstraction to a root cause that still has some connection to the original problem. Note that,

Prior Art (or Literature) Search The Prior Art Search (or Lit Search) forms the basis of your knowledge on the science and technology related to your design problem and should help your form your technical plan. Your reasons for conducting the search will include one or more of the following: To stimulate your thinking about solutions to your chosen problem (you should be solution neutral at this point) To recognize unaddressed user needs and emerging trends that influence the problems relevance To improve upon existing designs To see how your preliminary design ideas relate to the latest technology To identify parts of existing designs that may work for your project. To identify gaps and limitations in the current technological and scientific landscape To identify interdisciplinary connections and potential novel approaches to problem-solving To refine your problem statement by understanding existing solutions and their shortcomings
2 Confidential: For Classroom Use Only

Why?? Professional engineers conduct exhaustive prior art searches not only to honor the intellectual property of others, but also to stimulate ideas for advancing the technology. Likewise, by seeing what others have done, you can gain insights into what you can do differently and maybe better. You gain the most from a prior-art search if you begin it early in the project and if you continue to search as your problem and eventual solution develops.
Confidential: For Classroom Use Only 3

Peter Thiel’s View Under perfect competition, in the long run no company makes an economic profit. The opposite of perfect competition is monopoly. Whereas a competitive firm must sell at the market price, a monopoly owns its market, so it can set its own prices. Since it has no competition, it produces at the quantity and price combination that maximizes its profits. …by “monopoly,” we mean the kind of company that’s so good at what it does that no other firm can offer a close substitute. Google is a good example of a company that went from 0 to 1: it hasn’t competed in search since the early 2000s, when it definitively distanced itself from Microsoft and Yahoo! Every monopoly is unique, but they usually share some combination of the following characteristics: proprietary technology, network effects, economies of scale, and branding. As a good rule of thumb, proprietary technology must be at least 10 times better than its closest substitute in some

in some important dimension to lead to a real monopolistic advantage. Anything less than an order of magnitude better will probably be perceived as a marginal improvement and will be hard to sell, especially in an already crowded market. The clearest way to make a 10x improvement is to invent something completely new. Every startup is small at the start. Every monopoly dominates a large share of its market. Therefore, every startup should start with a very small market. Always err on the side of starting too small. The reason is simple: it’s easier to dominate a small market than a large one. If you think your initial market might be too big, it almost certainly is.
Confidential for classroom use only 3 Peter Thiel, From Zero to One (Crown Business : 2014) What will be a future monopoly is uncertain 3

Usher’s Model For purposes of generalized exposition, innovation can be formalized as a genetic sequence of four steps: Perception of a problem, an unfilled want whose gratification is made possible by the presence of some fortuitous conditions Setting of the stage, which serves as the basis for providing mediated contingencies that engender systematic efforts to find solutions to perceived problems through trial and error Act of insight, by which the essential solution of the problem is found The critical revision, where the solution is studied critically and understood in its fullness

Three Approaches for Solving Problems Brute Force Grid search of every potential solution until one works Example: Thomas Edison trying thousands of materials to determine the best filament for the lightbulb Targeted Development Theory informs potential solutions Example: Li-ion batteries developed with heavy guidance from research in electrochemical theory Eureka Moment Solution results from a chance event (randomness) Example: MOSFETs developed after accidentally discovering that current in a semiconductor can be controlled with electric field (rather than current, as in traditional bipolar junction transistors (BJTs)) 10 Confidential for classroom use only From Abbie Gibson How do you address a reverse salient – Abbie’s model. Could this also be used to predict the direction of technological advance. 10

Defining MECE MECE is a list.  It is a list of qualities lists should have.  [MECE] says that when data from a category is desired to be broken into subcategories, the choice of subcategories should be collectively exhaustive — i.e., the set of all subcategories, taken together, should fully characterize the larger category of which the data are part (“no gaps”) mutually exclusive — i.e., no subcategory should represent any other subcategory (“no overlaps”) This is desirable for the purpose of analysis: mutual exclusivity avoids the risk of double counting information, and collective exhaustion avoids the risk of overlooking information. In plain English, MECE says that a list should have No overlaps No gaps Confidential for classroom use only 20 One way to think about MECE is to create a grid – the question is what goes on the x and y axes,
axes, e.g. mechanisms and methods.  Think about your reason why analysis and the associated M’s, P’s, S’s, etc. 20
Issue Trees and Logic Trees Two areas for MECE thinking are in logic trees and issue trees.

Logic trees help you identify components of a problem. Start at the 20,000 foot view and move progressively downward. You may want to build multiple trees, for instance by business unit (organizational hierarchy) and functionally (production, sales, marketing, etc.) to see which leads you to the next step, the hypothesis. Issue trees let you rigorously test the hypothesis. They are different from logic trees. Logic trees are a hierarchical grouping of elements. Issue trees are the series of questions or issues that must be addressed to support or disprove a hypothesis. It becomes your roadmap for analysis.
Confidential for classroom use only 21

Why Use Issue Trees? To break a problem into component parts To ensure integrity of the problem solving is maintained To build a common understanding within the team of the problem-solving framework To help focus team efforts Confidential for classroom use only 22

Structure of an Issue Tree Confidential for classroom use only 23 Goal: Break a problem into component parts and show concrete solutions Question Formulation of the basic question to be resolved should be as specific as possible Idea 1 Idea 2 Idea 3 Idea 1.1 Idea 1.2 Idea 2.1 Idea 2.2 Idea 3.1 Idea 3.2 How / What? Level of detail Complete but non-overlapping list of conceivable solutions Further levels of detail for ideas, also complete and non-overlapping How / What?
Try This Example Confidential for classroom use only 24 Create a logic tree to address the following: How can you reduce monthly shopping expenses?

A Solution Confidential for classroom use only 25 How could you reduce your expenditure each month? Buy fewer items Food Clothing Travel Entertainment Share costs of items (e.g., split rent with roommate, carpool) Pay less for same quantity of items Buy lower-quality items Buy items at discount/on sale Make sure your solution is MECE 25

Summary: Doing MECE Break a problem down into smaller pieces that can serve as hypotheses to be tested Small pieces cannot overlap Sum of small parts must equal the big group Small elements must parallel each other, i.e. they must be in the same class or category Stick to the magical three

The Pareto Principle The Pareto Principle (also known as the “80/20 Rule” or the “Law of the Vital Few”) states that, for many events, roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes. It results from a ‘power law’ distribution.  Examples of this principle: Wealth: The top 20% of the population own more than 80% of the nations wealth. Science: The top 20% of published papers account for more than 80% of all cited works in subsequent publications. Computing: Fixing the top 20% of the most-reported bugs eliminates 80% of errors and crashes in a given system. Entertainment: The top 20% of titles make up more than 80% of viewers/listeners. Confidential for classroom use only 29 Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_principle: Pareto Principle Causes 20% Effects 80% Power
% Power Law Distribution Long Tail 80% Head 20%

Example: Solving the Problem of Medication Errors A medication error is a failure in the treatment process that leads to, or has the potential to lead to, harm to the patient. Per the NIH, recent studies of medical errors have estimated errors may account for as many as 251,000 deaths annually in the United States, making medical errors the third leading cause of death. Error rates are significantly higher in the U.S. than in other developed countries such as Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Germany and the United Kingdom. At the same time less than 10 percent of medical errors are reported. Confidential for classroom use only 32 32

Example: Medication Errors Per the WHO, there is no consensus about the definition of a medication error. A systematic literature review found 26 different terminologies employed for a medication error. Medication errors can occur in deciding which medicine and dosage regimen to use (prescribing faults—irrational, inappropriate, and ineffective prescribing, under-prescribing, over-prescribing); writing the prescription (prescription errors); manufacturing the formulation (wrong strength, contaminants or adulterants, wrong or misleading packaging); dispensing the formulation (wrong drug, wrong formulation, wrong label); administering or taking the medicine (wrong dose, wrong route, wrong frequency, wrong duration); monitoring therapy (failing to alter therapy when required, erroneous alteration). They can be classified, using a psychological classification of errors, as knowledge-, rule-, action- and memory-based errors. Although medication errors can occasionally be serious, they are not commonly so and are often trivial. However, it is important to detect them
detect them, since system failures that result in minor errors can later lead to serious errors. Confidential for classroom use only 33 https://academic.oup.com/qjmed/article/102/8/513/1598923

Overall Structure Rationale: The book moves from theoretical foundations to practical applications, starting with broad concepts and gradually becoming more specific and applied. It follows a logical progression from understanding what innovation is, to how to think about problems, to specific tools for finding and solving them.
Preface**

Suppose you wanted to create a startup?  How would you begin? This is the exercise that we have run (many times) at the start of our Innovation classes (both graduate and undergraduate) at Johns Hopkins University, Israel Institute of Technology, and Hebrew University, in addition to workshops all over the world. We ask students what’s the next big thing in e-commerce, or education, or saving the planet, or healthcare, or whatever timely topic shows up in the newspapers that day.

Students respond by getting together, and then brainstorm ideas. Others make lists of interesting and insightful people and ask them for ideas. Others walk down the street and try to see what is not there. Some search the newspapers for the latest world-altering disasters; or check social media for the latest hot trends. Others look at popular technology journals for the latest in scientific research, and so on.

But no matter what they do, the result is always the same. There are lots of ideas, almost all of them un-interesting. These are incredibly talented students, many of them engineers and scientists, often working in research labs on important and timely topics with famous professors. So why are their ideas so un-interesting?

Too many entrepreneurship courses assume that students already have a good idea, and the goal of the class is to validate the idea, find the best product-market fit, and figure out how to turn it into a real startup. Just as too many design classes assume that students already have a good problem to solve, and the goal of the class is to work through the design thinking process and develop that great solution. Everywhere you look there is an accelerator or incubator, some sponsored by universities themselves, but it is always the same – the assumption that you already have a good idea. And their job is to help you carry it forward and bring it to fruition.
That is not the goal of this book.
Introduction**

Innovation should need no introduction. It is the watchword of the day. It is woven into the history of global economic development; just as it is obvious to anyone who has ever tried to make their lives or jobs a little better.

Innovation is now an integral part of the curricula of engineering and business schools as well as a constant topic in boardrooms. Consultants peddle it as the panacea for corporate stagnation, the key to finding competitive advantage as products and markets mature.[[1]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21) Just as it is the key to grappling with a changing world.[[2]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21)

Governments offer programs to fund innovation and, as promised by the National Science Foundation’s Innovation Corps (I-Corps), teach people how “to reduce the time and risk associated with translating promising ideas and technologies from the laboratory to the marketplace.”[[3]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21) And again, the assumption is that the “promising ideas” are already present as natural extensions of people’s research and work.

But innovation is not simply a voluntary course of action taken at the discretion of inventors in a laboratory or at the direction of corporate executives hoping to revive a languishing business. More frequently, innovation is forced upon us, not just by a competitive marketplace, but by an uncertain, unpredictable, and dynamic world. Unfortunately, too many innovation efforts are consumed by incrementalism, on things that can be measured easily, on “presentism.” Expecting that the world will continue to behave just like it did last quarter or last year is not a realistic assumption. Everybody may want big, disruptive ideas, but instead always seem to chase narrowly focused, “present” ideas, those for which spreadsheets are most easily built and marketing materials most easily designed.

The events of the last few years have certainly emphasized this point. A 2021 article in *California Management Review* described COVID-19 as “a wake-up call that forced executives to rethink the very foundations of their business” and that they “have come to realize they must organize for dynamic systems by building agile, adaptive and resilient organizations.”[[4]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21) Disruptions, whether political, economic, social, or technical are likely to become the “new normal.” Needless to say, recent geo-political events have only emphasized the point:

The principles that have defined life in the United States – freedom, capitalism, individual effort – were the right ones for the past and remain so for the future. These basic values lie at the foundation of an innovation ecosystem that is still the envy of the world. The have enabled breakthroughs that have transformed everyday life around the world. The United States started the innovation race in pole position, but it cannot rest assured it will remain there. Silicon Valley’s old mantra holds true not just in industry but also in geopolitics: innovate or die.[[5]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21)

A prerequisite of organizational agility and adaptability is the *capacity to innovate;* the capacity to imagine different futures and how to proactively impact those futures rather than simply react to current pressures. It is by innovating – in product and service offerings, value propositions, business models, etc. – that businesses can successfully navigate, and possibly channel, the turbulent waters of an increasingly uncertain world. This capacity to innovate, of course, must be matched by an entrepreneurial capacity,[[6]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21) i.e. the ability to carry an innovation to market.

CEOs have taken notice. In the Conference Board’s *C-Suite Challenge 2021*, which surveyed more than 900 CEOs globally, CEOs cited the “lack of an innovation culture” as one of the top five obstacles their organizations currently face, and list “innovative thinking” as the most important quality they seek in future leaders.[[7]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21) So we have come to realize the wisdom in Peter Drucker’s famous observation that organizations must either “innovate or die.”[[8]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d

According to Drucker, innovation “is the specific instrument of entrepreneurship. It is the act that endows resources with a new capacity to create wealth. Innovation, indeed, creates a resource.”[[9]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21)

But how? Drucker’s answer will be our guideline: “Purposeful, systematic innovation begins with the analysis of the opportunities. Innovation is both conceptual and perceptual. The second imperative of innovation is therefore to go out to look, to ask, to listen.”[[10]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969?pvs=21)
SIDEBAR ABOUT PETER DRUCKER

“Purposeful, systematic innovation” begins with the hunt for opportunities, the core ideas that unleash innovation and innovative activities. This book is a guide to that hunt. It lays out the methodology that we have used with some success in our classrooms at Johns Hopkins University and elsewhere. This methodology embodies a structured set of tools, techniques, and templates for doing “purposeful, systematic innovation.” But with one important difference – we do not ask students to simply go out there “to look, to ask, to listen;” we do not want students simply to “get out of the building,” but to get out of their own heads, to escape from presentism by learning how to imagine alternative futures, and to do that imagining by working through a structured methodology.
In our approach, innovations require three components:
1. A problem worth solving; 2. A solution that solves the problem; and 3. A business case that makes sense and that allows the solution to enter the market and then scale.
What we have called *Innovation under Uncertainty* can be summarized in the following steps:

1. Form a cohort (or class) of 15-25 people. In general, they may be interested in specific subject areas (e.g. medical technologies, energy) or problem domains (e.g. cities, climate), but have no pre-formed ideas and who are open to exploring lots of possibilities. 2. Groups will be regularly formed and reformed from among the members of the cohort so that everybody has the chance to work with everybody else. 3. As groups, they explore un-defined and ill-defined spaces, tool by tool and template by template and question by question (based often on their own specific interests), as they build a bank of opportunities, dozens, or even many hundreds, strong. 4. They repeat this exploration process week after week (or as long as the class or workshop lasts), all the while moving further and further away from present thinking. 5. Groups validate, present, and defend their ideas to other groups every step of the way, sharp

way, sharpening the bank of opportunities. 6. Permanent teams slowly form. 7. Each team creates a small portfolio of opportunities around their favorite ideas; the best being those that take advantage of market and technological uncertainty while minimizing risk. 8. Teams present their small portfolios to the other teams (as well as outsiders); and then each team picks one to turn into a well-defined problem (teams may re-form at this point). 9. Each team further validates and refines the problem statement. 10. Teams continue to validate the problem while starting to design what a solution will have to deliver and the approach to be taken to actually create the solution. 11. Each team begins work on the solution even as they validate the solution for feasibility and adoptability. 12. Each team develops a business case for the solution. 13. After the solution has been designed (or an MVP actually built) and a business case developed, each team presents to an outside panel. 14. The best
. The best teams have the opportunity to move to an incubator.
The remainder of the book is designed to illustrate this process in greater detail, including the techniques, tools, and templates that we have developed, as well as some examples.
